Proposed Changes to ICD-9-CM Transfusion Associated Adverse Events
Proposed Changes to ICD-9-CM
Transfusion Associated
Adverse Events

September 17th, 2009
September 17th, 2009

ICD-9-CM Coordination and Maintenance Committee Meeting
ICD-9-CM Coordination and Maintenance Committee Meeting

Mikhail Menis, PharmD, MS Analytic Epidemiology Branch OBE/CBER/FDA
Mikhail Menis, PharmD, MS
Analytic Epidemiology Branch
OBE/CBER/FDA

Overview
Overview

• The FDA’s Center for Biologics Evaluation and Research
• The FDA’s Center for Biologics Evaluation and Research

(CBER) mission is to ensure safety and efficacy of biological products including blood and blood products and thus to protect and enhance public health.
(CBER) mission is to ensure safety and efficacy of biological
products including blood and blood products and thus to protect
and enhance public health.

• Under the Food and Drug Administration Amendments Act (FDAAA) of 2007, FDA is responsible for conducting U.S. population-based active surveillance of medical product safety including blood and blood product safety.
• Under the Food and Drug Administration Amendments Act
(FDAAA) of 2007, FDA is responsible for conducting U.S.
population-based active surveillance of medical product safety
including blood and blood product safety.

• Currently, we are using large medical databases from the
• Currently, we are using large medical databases from the

Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services, Health Maintenance Organizations and others to: – Conduct active surveillance of adverse events – Identify and characterize adverse events associated with the transfusion
Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services, Health Maintenance
Organizations and others to:
– Conduct active surveillance of adverse events
– Identify and characterize adverse events associated with the transfusion

of blood and blood products
of blood and blood products

Overview FDA/CBER submitted a proposal for consideration requesting the addition of new specific ICD-9-CM codes for transfusion- associated adverse reactions:
Overview
FDA/CBER submitted a proposal for consideration requesting the
addition of new specific ICD-9-CM codes for transfusion-
associated adverse reactions:

➢ Hemolytic Transfusion Reactions (HTRs)

T r a n s f u s i o n

•New Codes will help inform the development of better transfusion-related risk reduction strategies.
•New Codes will help inform the development of better
transfusion-related risk reduction strategies.

Hemolytic Transfusion Reaction (HTR)
Hemolytic Transfusion Reaction (HTR)

• A reaction of increased destruction of red blood cells
• A reaction of increased destruction of red blood cells

due to incompatibility between blood donor and recipient.
due to incompatibility between blood donor and
recipient.

• Clinical and laboratory signs of HTR: fever, chills,
• Clinical and laboratory signs of HTR: fever, chills,

rigors, hemoglobinuria, presence of antibodies to RBC antigens, etc.
rigors, hemoglobinuria, presence of antibodies to RBC
antigens, etc.

• HTR can be:
• HTR can be: • H T R

Hemolytic Transfusion Reactions (HTRs)
Hemolytic Transfusion Reactions (HTRs)

In FY 2008, HTRs were the leading cause of transfusion- related deaths reported to CBER, representing: ➢ 37% of confirmed transfusion-related fatalities ➢ 22% for ABO mismatch ➢ 15% for non-ABO mismatch
In FY 2008, HTRs were the leading cause of transfusion-
related deaths reported to CBER, representing:
➢ 37% of confirmed transfusion-related fatalities ➢ 3 7 %

Transfusion-Transmitted Infections (TTIs)
Transfusion-Transmitted Infections
(TTIs)

• TTIs include any infectious organism (bacteria, virus, parasite, other)
• TTIs include any infectious organism (bacteria, virus, parasite, other) • T T I s
i n c l u d e
a n y
i n f e c t i o u s
o r g a n i s m
( b a c t e r i a ,
v i r u s ,
p a r a s i t e ,
o t h e r )

transmitted through transfusion of blood or blood products (whole blood, RBCs, plasma, platelets, etc.)
transmitted through transfusion of blood or blood products (whole blood,
RBCs, plasma, platelets, etc.)

• Bacterial transfusion-transmitted infections include: gram-negative
• Bacterial transfusion-transmitted infections include: gram-negative • B a c t e r i a l
t r a n s f u s i o n - t r a n s m i t t e d
i n f e c t i o n s
i n c l u d e : g r a m - n e g a t i v e

organisms (e.g. Yersinia enterocolitica, Pseudomonas spp , Serratia spp), gram-positive organisms (e.g. Staphylococcus aureus, Staphylococcus epidermidis).
organisms (e.g. Yersinia enterocolitica, Pseudomonas spp , Serratia spp),
gram-positive organisms (e.g. Staphylococcus aureus, Staphylococcus
epidermidis).

• Viral transfusion-transmitted infections include: HIV, Hepatitis,
• Viral transfusion-transmitted infections include: HIV, Hepatitis, • V i r a l

i n f e c t i o n s

i n f e c t i o n s

C h a g a s ,

• Other (e.g. prion) transfusion-transmitted infections include: • O t h e r

Febrile Nonhemolytic Transfusion Reaction (FNHTR)
Febrile Nonhemolytic Transfusion
Reaction (FNHTR)

• FNHTR clinical signs include: fever, chills, rigors without hemolysis and occurs in the patient within 4 hours after transfusion.
• FNHTR clinical signs include: • F N H T R c l i n i c a l
s i g n s
i n c l u d e :
fever, chills, rigors without hemolysis and
occurs in the patient within 4 hours after
transfusion.

• Two most common reaction mechanisms:
• Two most common reaction mechanisms:

Posttransfusion Purpura (PTP)
Posttransfusion Purpura (PTP)

• PTP is characterized by sudden severe
• PTP is characterized by sudden severe • P T P i s
c h a r a c t e r i z e d
b y
s u d d e n
s e v e r e

thrombocytopenia (platelet count <10,000/µL) usually arising 5-12 days following transfusion of blood components (whole blood, RBCs, plasma, or platelets).
thrombocytopenia (platelet count <10,000/µL)
usually arising 5-12 days following transfusion
of blood components (whole blood, RBCs,
plasma, or platelets).

• Reaction associated with presence of
• Reaction associated with presence of

antibodies directed against the Human Platelet Antigen (HPA) system.
antibodies directed against the Human Platelet
Antigen (HPA) system.

• Characterized by acute respiratory distress, increased blood pressure, pulmonary edema secondary to congestive heart failure, positive fluid balance, etc. during or within 6 hours of transfusion.
• Characterized by acute respiratory distress, increased blood
pressure, pulmonary edema secondary to congestive heart
failure, positive fluid balance, etc. during or within 6 hours of
transfusion.

• Elderly and infants are at increased risk for TACO occurrence
• Elderly and infants are at increased risk for TACO occurrence

even with small transfusion volumes.
even with small transfusion volumes.

• Occurrence of TACO is very likely to be underreported due to a
• Occurrence of TACO is very likely to be underreported due to a

variety of differential diagnoses that present as Acute Respiratory Distress in the transfused persons including TRALI and anaphylaxis.
